newsitem.title: ZIMBABWE: ZIMBABWE DOLLAR ENDS WEAKER BUT SPREADS NARROWER.
newsitem.headline: ZIMBABWE DOLLAR ENDS WEAKER BUT SPREADS NARROWER.

text.p: The Zimbabwe dollar closed Monday's interbank session easier on the U.S. dollar but dealers said normality seemed to be returning to the market after the local currency went on a free-fall stretching over a week on the back of import pressure.
"Rates are still high but the situation seems to be returning to normal though it hasn't completely normalised as yet," one dealer said.

The Zimbabwe dollar lost some 10 cents in little over a week on the back of import pressure compounded by central bank governor Leonard Tsumba's statements published in a financial newspaper twe Fridays ago that the unit was overvalued against the U.S. dollar.
At some point during the period dealers were quoting bid/offer spreads as wide as 20 points to protect their foreign currency reserves.
At Monday's close, the Zimbabwe dollar was quoted at 11.6350/6550 on the U.S. dollar, weaker compared to Friday's 11.5700/6700 but a point away from the normal one-point spread.

On the crosses, it was quoted firmer against sterling at 18.9500/9780 from 19.0170/0230, tracking a stronger U.S. dollar overseas and was at 6.2300/2380 from 6.3130/3175 versus the mark and at 2.4980/5020 against South Africa's rand from 2.5290/5325.
